Class Digit

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
math.core.Digit
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Digit>, EnhancedOperable<Digit>, Operable<Digit>
public class Digit extends Number implements EnhancedOperable<Digit>
Turns any primitive given number or a real number as string into a full notationed readable number.

Represents arbitrary-precision decimal numbers with configurable notation formatting. This class provides immutable numeric values that can exceed primitive type limits, along with comprehensive arithmetic operations, comparisons, and formatting capabilities.

Key Features:

  • Arbitrary Precision - Handles real numbers of virtually unlimited size (memory permitting)
  • Multiple Notation Systems - Supports decimal point (1,234.56) or comma (1.234,56) formats
  • Full Arithmetic Operations - Addition, subtraction, multiplication, division with precision control
  • Advanced Mathematical Functions - Inverse, modulus, rounding, and sign operations
  • Comparison Utilities - Specialized methods for comparing to zero, one, and minus one
  • Type Conversion - Implements all Number primitive conversions
  • Immutable Design - Thread-safe implementation with value semantics
Core Capabilities
CategoryMethods
ConstructionFrom String, double, long pairs, or component parts
Arithmeticadd, subtract, multiply, divide, inverse, module
ComparisoncompareTo, compareToZero, compareToOne, compareToMinusOne
Sign Operationsnegate, abs, increase, decrease
FormattingtoString, stringValue
Precision ControlsetScale (rounding modes), inverse (precision)

Technical Implementation Notes:

  • Numbers stored as separate integer and decimal string components
  • Delegates arithmetic operations to Operationer utility
  • Uses Notationer for number formatting and parsing
  • Implements EnhancedOperable for advanced math operations
  • Supports all standard rounding modes (RoundingMode)

Usage Example:



		Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);

		System.out.print(n);//12,345,600
Since:
v0.0.1
See Also:
  • Operationer
  • Notationer

  • Method Details

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Implements the String format() function from extended class Notationer to print the number on a readable notation using the attributes this.integerPart, this.decimalPart and this.notation as parameters for such function. The return values will be either negative or positive depending on the state of the attribute this.isNegative.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      String Returns a full notationed readable number.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
      See Also:
      • Notationer.format(String, String, boolean)

      public boolean equals(Object obj)
      Implements the boolean equals(Object) function from extended class class Object to compare the instances.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);
			Digit m = new Digit("89");

			boolean result = n.equals(m);
      The return value will be result = false
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      obj - Object instance.
      Returns:
      boolean Returns a boolean value where true means the instances are equal and false means they are not.

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(Digit n)
      Implements the int compareTo(Object) function from implemented class Comparable to compare the instances.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);
			Digit m = new Digit("89");

			int result = n.compareTo(m);
      The return value will be result = 1
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<Digit>
      Parameters:
      n - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      int Returns an x value ranging from -1<x<1 where x belongs to integers. Where 0 if both are equal, 1 if n>m and -1 if n<m.
      Since:
      v0.0.3s
      See Also:
      • Comparable.compareTo(Object)
      • Operationer.compareIntegerParts(String, String)

			int result = n.compareToZero();

    • inverse

      public Digit inverse()
      Calculates the Digit instance's inverse value with the precision set at 128. Overriding the implemented function inverse from Operable interface.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit(2);
			Digit m = n.inverse();
      The return value will be m = 0.5
      Specified by:

    • add

      public Digit add(Digit other)
      Adds two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially. Overriding the implemented function add from Operable interface.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("-123.45");
			Digit m = new Digit(678.9);

			Digit result = n.add(m);
      The return value will be result = 555.45
      Specified by:
      add in interface Operable<Digit>
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the addition of the two instance.
      Since:
      v0.0.4
      See Also:
      • negate()
      • abs()

    • multiply

      public Digit multiply(Digit other)
      Multiplies two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially. Overriding the implemented function multiply from Operable interface.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("25");
			Digit m = new Digit(5);

			Digit result = n.multiply(m);
      The return value will be result = 125
      Specified by:
      multiply in interface Operable<Digit>

    • divide

      public Digit divide(Digit other)
      Divides two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially with the precision set at 128. Overriding the implemented function divide from Operable interface.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("7");
			Digit m = new Digit(4);

			Digit result = n.divide(m);
      The return value will be result = 1.75
      Specified by:
      divide in interface Operable<Digit>
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the division of the two instance.
      Throws:
      UndeterminedException - if Digit other is zero.
      Since:
      v0.1.1
      See Also:
      • Operable.divide(Object)
      • divide(Digit, long)

    • divide

      public Digit divide(Digit other, long precision)
      Divides two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("7");
			Digit m = new Digit(4);

			Digit result = n.divide(m, 16);
      The return value will be result = 1.75
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      precision - Decimal precision.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the division of the two instance.
      Throws:
      UndeterminedException - if Digit other is zero.

      v0.0.6

    • module

      public Digit module(Digit other)
      Gets the module between two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      a mod b = |a| - |b| * FLOOR(|a|/|b|)

      The sign of the result will be the original sign from a.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("4");
			Digit m = new Digit(2);

			Digit result = n.module(m);
      The return value will be result = 0
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the module of the firts instance given the second instance.
      Throws:
      UndeterminedException - if Digit other is zero.
      Since:
      v0.0.8
      See Also:
      • abs()
      • subtract(Digit)
      • multiply(Digit)
      • divide(Digit, long)

    • setScale

      public Digit setScale(int scale, RoundingMode mode)
      Rounds the number given a scale and a rounding mode.

      Usage Example 
      

			Digit n = new Digit("1.56");

			Digit result = n.setScale(1, RoundingMode.HALF_UP);
      The return values will be result = 1.6
      Parameters:
      scale - Decimal scale.
      mode - Rounding mode.
      Returns:
      Digit Rounded instance.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - if RoundingMode mode is not either a given constant for RoundingMode class or the constant is RoundingMode.UNNECESARY.
      Since:
      v0.0.8
      See Also:
      • RoundingMode
